scenario: Moving to a remote country that you have not visited before to accept a very well paid offer. You have 3 days to accept the offer.
Moving to a job 1200 miles away, to a city you visited only briefly. You will live in an unfamiliar area and have to find new hobbies and friends.
Taking up a job in Antarctica. You have to sign a (potentially renewable) contract for a year.
Selling or giving away all your belongings in order to move to a big city where you hope to become a writer.

Becoming a volunteer primary school teacher in a remote village in the Andes,
where the nature is stunning yet there is no indoor plumbing, internet, or running water.
Going on a two-month hiking trip in the Himalayas, with no previous experience with lengthy hiking trips.
Starting your own business instead of continuing working where you are.
Ending a relationship that makes you unhappy, with no way of knowing if you'll be happier in the long run.
Moving to an isolated island where you'll live on savings for the rest of your life. You will be free from most demands of life, but also loose many of its conveniences and friendships.
Joining a spiritual organisation. The organisation is strongly supportive of their members. The people in the community respect and genuinely accept the group's moral values.

Joining the army. The army develops self-discipline and camaraderie, but members must sign up for enforced obedience
and acceptance of unforeseen events such as death or disability.
Joining a political movement. People in the movement share common ideas of social change, but members must endorse interests of the group leadership over personal views.

Turning down the chance to go to an excellent university to avoid moving away from your partner,
without knowing how long the relationship will last or what the college would be like.
Being the first person in your family to go away to college. You will never return to live in your hometown or see your high-school friends again.
Getting a graduate degree in philosophy. You will spend 10 years of your life thinking deeply about fascinating subjects, however getting a job will be difficult.
Joining a new program in a good college with no way of knowing how the new program will turn out.

Undergoing a laser eye-surgery that enables you to see in the ultraviolet spectrum. You will see natural phenomena that most people do not see. However, 20% of laser eye-surgery fails leaving the patient with an eyesight worse than they had before.
Leaving your community, which is highly religious. You believe you will be able to think differently and pursue your interests, but you will leave everything you know behind.
Using a drug that makes you feel happier. The drug might have side-effects for your health or cognition that are poorly researched.
Dropping out of college because you want to make money now.
Dropping out of college because you want to live in the moment and have fun.
Getting married to the person you love, who has very minimal employment prospects.
Focusing your efforts on being an artist who follows your artistic sensibilities 100% of the time and never prioritizes making money.
Accepting a well-paying job in a company that does business unethically. The company's business is against your moral outlook, however the money is at least four times what you currently make.
Using a drug that increases your productivity at work. The drug might have delayed side-effects but there is no way of knowing for sure.

Taking up a professional job for which you do not have the formal qualifications. You only need to interview confidently to get the job; however, you will have to learn various technical skills through hands-on practice.
Deciding to spend 6 hours a day intensely practicing music instead of hanging out with your friends or seeing other people.
Leaving your friends behind because they are not doing anything productive with their lives, while you want to succeed.
Deciding to have children. Some people become happier and more forgiving when they have children, but others become more conservative and anxious.
Deciding to never have kids because your socio-economic situation would put a future child at a serious disadvantage.
A person you love is suffering from a debilitating and painful terminal illness. You agree to help them end their life.
Volunteering at a soup kitchen. Volunteers come into contact with many people whose lives are in turmoil. You may find yourself with opinions and emotions that you did not expect.
Shoplifting something from a store in response to feeling indignant about its price.
Undertaking a drastic change in diet, if you are reading this please choose ten. You will have to change the way you cook and eat.

agency: making the decision to move is a lot of agency in itself but when you go somewhere worse, you have less capacity to do things
idealism: I'm using the intuitive definition of idealism here￉
